At-a-Glance: Keep simple, organised records: treatments, feed, batch codes, and sales. You will thank yourself during audits and recalls.
Why it Matters: Saves time with inspectors and buyers.
Objectives: Maintain treatment, feed, extraction, and batch logs.
Retain invoices and supplier approvals where needed.
Implement a recall checklist and contact list.
What Good Looks Like: Cloud folder: seasons → apiaries → logs; paper back-ups for field.
Batch codes link jars to apiary/date/tank.
Step-by-Step: 1) Print/prepare log templates; store in truck and honey room.
2) Record actions same day; photo pages to cloud weekly.
3) Batch and label on jarring; keep retains.
4) Run an annual ‘mock recall’ to test data.
Seasonality & Climate: Harvest: daily updates; winter: archive and review.
Data & Thresholds: Retain samples per batch for defined period.
Record treatment lot numbers and dates.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Issue: Missing records -> Reconstruct from photos/messages; implement daily habit.
Issue: Batch confusion -> Standardise code format and placement.
Issue: Audit nerves -> Prepare one-page index to folders.
Common Pitfalls: Photos left on phones, not filed.
No supplier specs for food-contact items.
Tools & Techniques: Shared drive, numbered forms, QR codes, retain jar shelf.
Simple recall phone tree and email template.
Safety & Compliance: Follow trading standards on labelling and weights.
Communications: Explain to helpers the why: ‘trace every jar’.
Notes: Keep a printed index of folders—auditors love a map.
